Journal.Title: Journal of the American Chemical Society

Article.ArticleTitle: Cascade Charge Transitions of Unusually High and Mixed Valence Fe<sup>3.5+</sup> in the A-Site Layer-Ordered Double Perovskite SmBaFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>6</sub>.

AbstractText: The A-site layer-ordered double perovskite SmBaFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>6</sub> was obtained by topochemical of oxidizing A-site layer-ordered SmBaFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub> in ozone at a low temperature. The compound contained unusually high and mixed valence Fe<sup>3.5+</sup> and was found to show cascade charge transitions, described as SmBaFe<sup>3.5+</sup><sub>2</sub>O<sub>6</sub> → SmBa(Fe<sup>3+</sup>Fe<sup>4+</sup>)O<sub>6</sub> → SmBa(Fe<sup>3+</sup>Fe<sup>(4-δ)+</sup><sub>0.5</sub>Fe<sup>(4+δ)+</sup><sub>0.5</sub>)O<sub>6</sub> → SmBa(Fe<sup>3+</sup><sub>1.5</sub>Fe<sup>5+</sup><sub>0.5</sub>)O<sub>6</sub>, to relieve its electronic instability. The first Verwey-like charge-order transition occurred at 340 K and was accompanied by a significant structural change and a sudden increase in magnetic susceptibility. The following transition was the charge disproportionation of metastable Fe<sup>4+</sup> to Fe<sup>3+</sup> and Fe<sup>5+</sup>, and each of the spins resulted in the antiferromagnetic ground state. The most plausible charge-ordered patterns are proposed based on the electrostatic lattice energy calculations.
